[[Winter storm]]
[[Nor'easter]]
[[Blizzard]] |date formed = {{start date|2015|01|23}} |date dissipated = {{start date|2015|01|31}} |RSI = 6.16 |maximum amount = {{convert|36.0|in|cm|abbr=on}} in [[Lunenburg, Massachusetts|Lunenburg]], [[Milford, Massachusetts|Milford]], [[Auburn, Massachusetts|Auburn]], and [[Massachusetts|Hudson]], and [[Maynard, Massachusetts]] |pressure = {{convert|970|mbar|inHg|abbr=on}} |1-min winds = 65 |gust = {{convert|95|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}{{cite web|url=http://www.weather.com/storms/winter/news/winter-storm-juno-blizzard-boston-nyc-new-england|title=Winter Storm Juno Hammering New England|date=January 26, 2015|work=The Weather Channel|accessdate=January 27, 2015}} |damages = Unknown |areas affected = [[Pacific Northwest]], [[Central United States]], [[Eastern United States]], [[Atlantic Canada]], Southern [[Greenland]], [[Portugal]], [[Spain]], [[France]] |total fatalities = 3 total |notes = Part of the '''[[2014–15 North American winter]]''' }} The '''January 2015 North American blizzard''' was a powerful and severe [[blizzard]] that dumped up to {{convert|3|ft|mm}} of snowfall in parts of [[New England]]. Originating from a disturbance just off the coast of the [[Northwestern United States]] on January 23, it initially produced a light swath of snow as it traveled southeastwards into the Midwest as an [[Alberta clipper]] on January 24–25. It gradually weakened as it moved eastwards towards the Atlantic Ocean, however, a new dominant low formed off the [[East Coast of the United States]] late on January 26, and rapidly deepened as it moved northeastwards towards southeastern New England, producing pronounced blizzard conditions. The nor’easter then gradually weakened as it moved away into Canada. The storm was also given unofficial names, such as ''Blizzard of 2015'', and ''Winter Storm Juno''. The nor'easter disrupted transportation, with [[snow emergency|snow emergencies]] declared in six states and travel bans enacted in four of these states – [[Connecticut]], [[New Jersey]], [[Massachusetts]], and [[Rhode Island]] – as well as in [[New York City]]. Most [[passenger rail]] service was suspended, and thousands of flights were cancelled. Schools and activities saw [[weather-related cancellation]]s for one or more days. Before the blizzard struck, meteorologists had been anticipating that the impending storm would be "historic" and "record-breaking", with predictions of snowfall accumulations in major metropolitan areas such as [[New York City]] of up to {{convert|2–3|ft|in}}. However, the predictions fell significantly short of what was anticipated, mainly due to a shift of the storm’s track, which cut down on the amount of snowfall. In the aftermath of the storm, citizens criticised the local government for shutting down the subway system in New York City for the storm. ==Meteorological history== {{storm path|January 2015 Nor'easter track.png}} On January 23, a [[low-pressure area]] developed off the [[Pacific Northwest]], before moving over the [[Canadian Prairies]] by January 24. The storm system quickly moved southeastward into the [[Upper Midwest]] during the evening of January 24, taking a path typical of an [[Alberta clipper]].{{cite web|last1=Rubin-Oster |first1=Brenden |title=Short Range Public Discussion Jan 24 2015 335 AM EST |url=http://www.hpc.ncep.noaa.gov/discussions/hpcdiscussions.php?disc%3Dpmdspd%26version%3D3%26fmt%3Dreg |website=Weather Prediction Center |publisher=United States National Weather Service |accessdate=January 26, 2015 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/6VrGhHOzl?url=http://www.hpc.ncep.noaa.gov/discussions/hpcdiscussions.php?disc=pmdspd&version=3&fmt=reg |dead-url=yes |archivedate=January 26, 2015 |location=College Park, Maryland |date=January 24, 2015 |df= }}{{cite web|last1=Petersen |first1=Daniel |title=Probabilistic Heavy Snow And Icing Discussion Jan 23 2015 3:17AM EST |url=http://www.hpc.ncep.noaa.gov/discussions/hpcdiscussions.php?disc=qpfhsd&version=5&fmt=reg |publisher=Weather Prediction Center |accessdate=January 26, 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6VrIW6h8k?url=http://www.hpc.ncep.noaa.gov/discussions/hpcdiscussions.php?disc=qpfhsd&version=5&fmt=reg |archivedate=January 26, 2015 |location=College Park, Maryland |date=January 23, 2015 |deadurl=yes |df= }} As it progressed southward, the storm intensified, with [[frontogenesis]] occurring the next day.{{cite web|last1=Petersen |first1=Daniel |title=Probabilistic Heavy Snow And Icing Discussion Jan 24 2015 3:49AM EST |url=http://www.hpc.ncep.noaa.gov/discussions/hpcdiscussions.php?disc=qpfhsd&version=1&fmt=reg |publisher=Weather Prediction Center |accessdate=January 26, 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6VrJ19WkK?url=http://www.hpc.ncep.noaa.gov/discussions/hpcdiscussions.php?disc=qpfhsd&version=1&fmt=reg |archivedate=January 26, 2015 |location=College Park, Maryland |date=January 24, 2015 |deadurl=yes |df= }} By noon on January 25, the upper-level low was centered near the border between [[Iowa]] and [[Missouri]] in correlation with a weak [[Shortwave (meteorology)|shortwave trough]]. Moisture from the [[Gulf of Mexico]] wrapped around the system from the south, resulting in widespread rainfall and snow over the [[Midwest]].{{cite web|author1=Office of Satellite and Product Operation|title=Satellite Precipitation Estimates Jan 25 2015 1545Z|url=http://www.ospo.noaa.gov/data/atmosphere/precip/spe/messages/2015/201501251545.html|website=National Environmental Satellite, Data, and Information Service|publisher=National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|accessdate=January 26, 2015|date=January 25, 2015}} Throughout the day, the system traversed eastward along the [[Kentucky]]-[[Tennessee]] border. Snowfall remained concentrated along a [[cold front]] north of the [[Ohio River]].{{cite web|author1=Office of Satellite and Product Operation|title=Satellite Precipitation Estimates Jan 25 2015 1945Z|url=http://www.ospo.noaa.gov/data/atmosphere/precip/spe/messages/2015/201501252004.html|website=National Environmental Satellite, Data, and Information Service|publisher=National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|accessdate=January 26, 2015|date=January 25, 2015}} [[File:Blizzard2015PrecursorJan252015.png|thumb|right|250px|The precursor to the blizzard tracking across the Ohio Valley, as an [[Alberta clipper]] on January 25, 2015.]] At 09:00 [[Universal Time Coordinate|UTC]] on January 26, the [[Weather Prediction Center]] began issuing storm summaries on the developing disturbance while the low-pressure system was centered near [[Bluefield, West Virginia]]. At the time, [[rain and snow mixed|mixed precipitation]] was occurring over northern [[Appalachia]].{{cite web|last1=Fanning |first1=Amanda |title=Storm Summary Number 01 For Mid-Atlantic To Northeast Major Winter Storm |website=Weather Prediction Center |publisher=National Centers for Environmental Prediction |url=http://www.hpc.ncep.noaa.gov/winter_storm_summaries/storm2/stormsum_1.html |accessdate=January 26, 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6VscS6iNd?url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/winter_storm_summaries/storm2/stormsum_1.html |archivedate=January 26, 2015 |location=College Park, Maryland |date=January 26, 2015 |deadurl=yes |df= }}{{cite web|author1=Office of Satellite and Product Operation|title=Satellite Precipitation Estimates Jan 26 2015 0915Z|url=http://www.ospo.noaa.gov/data/atmosphere/precip/spe/messages/2015/201501260924.html|website=National Environmental Satellite, Data, and Information Service|publisher=National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|accessdate=January 26, 2015|date=January 26, 2015}} As this system tracked eastward, it gradually weakened;{{cite web|last1=Petersen |first1=Daniel |title=Probabilistic Heavy Snow And Icing Discussion Jan 26 2015 4:07AM EST |url=http://www.hpc.ncep.noaa.gov/discussions/hpcdiscussions.php?disc=qpfhsd&version=1&fmt=reg |publisher=Weather Prediction Center |accessdate=January 26, 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6VsdZWdTQ?url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/discussions/hpcdiscussions.php?disc=qpfhsd&version=1&fmt=reg |archivedate=January 26, 2015 |location=College Park, Maryland |date=January 26, 2015 |deadurl=yes |df= }} however, at the same time, a new low-pressure system formed off the coast of [[North Carolina]] and began to track north-northeastward, eventually becoming the dominant low of the storm.{{cite web|last1=Kong |first1=Kwan-yin |title=Storm Summary Number 02 For Mid-Atlantic To Northeast Major Winter Storm |website=Weather Prediction Center |publisher=National Centers for Environmental Prediction |url=http://www.hpc.ncep.noaa.gov/winter_storm_summaries/storm2/stormsum_2.html |accessdate=January 26, 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6VsdUg5qy?url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/winter_storm_summaries/storm2/stormsum_2.html |archivedate=January 26, 2015 |location=College Park, Maryland |date=January 26, 2015 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Early on January 30, the nor'easter left the East Coast, even as another winter storm began to impact the region.{{cite web|url=http://www.weather.com/storms/winter/news/winter-storm-kari-snow-forecast|title=Winter Storm Kari Blankets Snow-Weary New England|date=January 29, 2015|work=The Weather Channel}} During the next day, the former nor'easter continued to accelerate eastward across the North Atlantic, even as it rapidly weakened.{{cite web |url=http://www.met.fu-berlin.de/de/wetter/maps/Analyse_20150130.gif |title=Fu-Berlin Map |format=gif |date=30 January 2015 |accessdate=1 March 2015}} On January 31, the winter storm was absorbed by a much more powerful [[extratropical cyclone]] developing over [[Western Europe]].{{cite web |url=http://www.met.fu-berlin.de/de/wetter/maps/Analyse_20150131.gif |title=Fu-Berlin Map |format=gif |date=31 January 2015 |accessdate=1 March 2015}} ===Forecasting controversy=== A number of New York City residents criticized New York Governor [[Andrew Cuomo]]'s decision to shut down the [[New York City Subway|city's subway system]]; it had never previously been closed due to snow. The nor'easter dropped much less snow in the city than originally expected, totaling {{convert|9.8|in|cm}} in [[Central Park]]. The models were 50 miles off; the storm failed to bring moisture back to New York City and New Jersey.{{cite web|last1=Flegenheimer|first1=Matt|title=Leaders in New York and New Jersey Defend Shutdown for a Blizzard That Wasn’t|url=http://nytimes.com/2015/01/28/nyregion/new-york-blizzard.html?referrer=|website=New York Times|publisher=The New York Times Company|accessdate=28 January 2015}}{{cite web|last1=Dolce|first1=Chris|last2=Lam|first2=Linda|last3=Wiltgen|first3=Nick|title=Juno: Heavy Snow Continues in New England|url=http://www.weather.com/storms/winter/news/winter-storm-juno-blizzard-boston-nyc-new-england|website=Weather.com|publisher=The Weather Channel, LLC|accessdate=28 January 2015}} ==Preparations== On January 25, 2015, blizzard warnings were issued for areas of coastal [[New England]], [[New York (state)|New York]] and [[New Jersey]].{{cite web|author=Linda Lam|author2=Chris Dolce|title=Winter Storm Juno: Blizzard Warnings for New York City, Boston, Parts of 7 States; Potentially Historic Northeast Snowstorm Ahead|url=http://www.weather.com/storms/winter/news/winter-storm-juno-snow-clipper-midwest-mid-atlantic-northeast-storm-early-week|publisher=The Weather Channel|date=January 26, 2015|accessdate=January 26, 2015}} High winds and heavy snow were forecast for the evening of January 26 and all day January 27, impacting a 250-mile area from [[New York City]] to [[Boston]].{{cite web|author=Verena Dobnik|title=Nor'easter threatens Northeast with up to 2 feet of snow|url=http://ipad.aol.com/article/2015/01/25/blizzard-like-conditions-possible-in-northeasts-next-storm/21134475/|agency=Associated Press|publisher=AOL|date=January 26, 2015|accessdate=January 26, 2015}} On January 26, many roads in New York and New England were closed to all vehicles except emergency vehicles due to life-threatening conditions on area roadways.{{cite web | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/01/27/nyregion/new-york-blizzard.html?_r=0 | title=Snowstorm Barrels Into Northeast; New York City Subways and Buses Are Halted | work=The New York Times | date=January 26, 2015 | accessdate=January 26, 2015 | author=Marc Santora}}{{cite web|url = http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2927832/60million-people-hit-shutdown-roads-tunnels-trains-bridges-businesses-brought-standstill-THREE-FEET-snow-threatens-country-s-densely-populated-areas.html|title=North East coast of America on unprecedented lockdown: Road and train travel banned and businesses closed as 60 million people warned to stay indoors today in anticipation of deadly blizzard |date=January 26, 2015|work=Daily Mail|accessdate=January 27, 2015}} Many [[church (building)|churches]] and other houses of prayer remained open to those in need of a [[warming center]]. At the height of the storm, a 300-mile (480 km) stretch of [[Interstate 95]] from northern New Jersey to the Massachusetts/New Hampshire border was closed in conjunction with travel bans in the impacted areas. Portions of Interstates [[Interstate 78|78]], [[Interstate 80|80]], [[Interstate 84 (East)|84]], [[Interstate 87 (New York)|87]], [[Interstate 90|90]], [[Interstate 91|91]] and [[Interstate 93|93]] were also shut down by the storm. ===Pennsylvania=== In preparation for the winter storm, the [[Pennsylvania Department of Transportation]] deployed approximately 350 salting trucks to treat major roadways.{{cite news|title=NWS: 18–24 inches for Burlington and Lower Bucks; 14–18 for parts of Bucks, Montco|url=http://www.burlingtoncountytimes.com/news/state/nj/nws---inches-for-burlington-and-lower-bucks-/article_6a389467-d043-5c8c-a934-0e879d070888.html|newspaper=Burlington County Times|date=January 25, 2015|accessdate=January 25, 2015}} On January 26, Pennsylvania Governor [[Tom Wolf (politician)|Tom Wolf]] signed a disaster emergency proclamation in an attempt to distribute state resources as quickly as possible.{{cite news|author=Howard Sheppard|title=Governor signs disaster emergency proclamation|url=http://fox43.com/2015/01/26/governor-signs-disaster-emergency-proclamation-2/|work=Fox 43 News|date=January 26, 2015|accessdate=January 26, 2015}} Philadelphia Mayor [[Michael Nutter]] closed municipal offices and schools for January 27 and cancelled trash collection for the day. Meanwhile, [[SEPTA]]'s bus lines closed while its train system ran 24 hours a day for Monday and Tuesday. According to the [[Philadelphia Office of Emergency Management]], the snow emergency declaration was lifted at 6:00 a.m. Tuesday morning.{{cite web | last = Berger | first = Michele| last2 = Bonaccorso | first2 = N.| title = Philadelphia, Mid-Atlantic States: Less Snow Than Expected from Juno| publisher = [[The Weather Channel]]| date = January 27, 2015| url = http://www.weather.com/storms/winter/news/winter-storm-juno-midatlantic-impacts| accessdate = January 27, 2015 }} ===New Jersey=== The South Brunswick Police Department said in a press release on January 25 that additional officers and public works staff would be on duty throughout the storm. The department urged residents to make preparations in anticipation that travel would be impossible for several days. The Monroe Township Office of Emergency Management released a guideline to ensure residents were safe and prepared for the nor'easter.{{cite web|author=Charles Kim|title=Region prepares for possible blizzard|url=http://www.centraljersey.com/articles/2015/01/25/topstory/doc54c540364259a766410194.txt|publisher=Central Jersey|date=January 25, 2015|accessdate=January 25, 2015}} New Jersey Governor [[Chris Christie]] declared a [[state of emergency]] for the duration of the storm; in a morning press conference, Christie also urged all nonessential personnel to remain off roadways.{{cite news|author=Susan Livio|title=Christie declares state of emergency for N.J. blizzard, urges residents to stay home|url=http://www.nj.com/politics/index.ssf/2015/01/christie_declares_a_state_of_emergency_ahead_of_sn.html|work=NJ Advance Media|date=January 26, 2015|accessdate=January 26, 2015}} A travel ban was issued later that day, to be put in effect on January 26 at 11 pm; [[Amtrak]] and [[New Jersey Transit]] services were also suspended. ===New York=== In a statement on January 25, [[New York Governor]] [[Andrew Cuomo]] urged residents to take their necessary safety precautions and prepare for the possibility of disrupted commute on Monday and Tuesday. The [[Metropolitan Transportation Authority]] deployed extra crews, salting trucks, and chained tires. [[Delta Air Lines]] promised full refunds for flights significantly delayed.{{cite news|title=Going Somewhere? Planes, Trains and Automobiles Prep for Blizzard|url=http://www.abreakingnews.com/local/going-somewhere-planes-trains-and-automobiles-prep-for-blizzard-h340607.html|work=A Breaking News|date=January 25, 2015|accessdate=January 25, 2015}} The State Emergency Operations Center in [[Albany, New York|Albany]] was expected to be staffed beginning early on January 26 to coordinate with all affected counties. At least 1,806 plows and 126,000 tons of salt were expected to be divided across the region, and the [[National Guard of the United States|National Guard]] was expected to deploy more than six dozen personnel and 20 vehicles throughout the region. New York State Police were expected to bring in additional personnel, as well as supply at least 50 4x4 vehicles, 8 all-terrain vehicles, and 8 snowmobiles. At its major transportation facilities, the [[Port Authority of New York and New Jersey]] readied more than 200 piece of snow equipment at its airports, more than 60 pieces of snow equipment for its bridges and tunnels, hundreds of thousands of gallons of liquid anti-icer chemicals and thousands of tons of solid de-icers, plow-equipped trains, liquid snow-melting agent trains, and a "jet engine" plow. The [[New York State Thruway Authority]] activated its emergency operations ahead of the winter storm and is expected to supply 338 snowplows, 18 snowblowers, 55 front-end loaders, and approximately 126,000 tons of salt. The [[New York State Department of Transportation]] also activated its emergency operations, mobilizing 162 snow plows and nearly 338 operators to [[Long Island]] and the [[Hudson Valley]], totaling to approximately 600 plows and 1,300 operators and supervisors across [[downstate New York]]. A total of 1,444 snow plows and 3,629 operators and supervisors would be available statewide.{{cite web|title=Governor Cuomo Urges New Yorkers to Prepare for Major Snowstorm Forecasted to Hit Downstate Areas on Monday and Tuesday|url=https://www.governor.ny.gov/news/governor-cuomo-urges-new-yorkers-prepare-major-snowstorm-forecasted-hit-downstate-areas-monday|publisher=New York State|date=January 25, 2015|accessdate=January 25, 2015|location=Albany, New York}} [[New York City Mayor]] [[Bill de Blasio]] warned of {{convert|2|to|3|ft}} of snow, and said, "Prepare for something worse than we have seen before."[http://abcnews.go.com/US/major-noreaster-disrupt-travel-millions-bringing-heavy-snow/story?id=28465864 Major Nor'easter to Disrupt Travel for Millions Bringing Heavy Snow and Blizzard Conditions] ABC News, January 25, 2015 De Blasio ordered all vehicles off the streets by 11 pm on January 26, and declared that, with the exception of emergency and government vehicles, anyone driving in New York City after 11 pm on January 26 would be fined. Services on the [[New York City Subway]], [[Long Island Rail Road]], [[Metro-North Railroad]], and [[Amtrak]] were also suspended. ===Connecticut=== Connecticut Governor [[Dannel Malloy]] announced in a press conference early on January 26 that [[Connecticut Transit]] services would be suspended and a statewide travel ban would be effective beginning at 9 p.m EST; he also urged all residents to leave work early and shelter in their homes. The [[Metropolitan Transportation Authority]] announced that it would be adding additional trains to accommodate for those who travel by rail. The governor announced that more than 600 crews would be working to pre-treat major roads, while he issued a declaration of civil preparedness emergency to coordinate resources during the storm.{{cite news|title=Travel Ban Issued, Schools Dismiss in Advance of Blizzard|url=http://www.nbcconnecticut.com/news/local/Possible-Coastal-Storm-Could-Bring-Noreaster-289682371.html|work=NBC Connecticut|date=January 26, 2015|accessdate=January 26, 2015}} [[Connecticut Light and Power]] and [[United Illuminating]] prepared for a "Level 1" emergency and summoned outside tree and line crews.{{cite news|title=Governor Orders Travel Ban As of 9 p.m.|url=http://connecticut.cbslocal.com/2015/01/26/governor-orders-travel-plan-as-of-9-p-m/|work=CBS Connecticut|date=January 26, 2015|accessdate=January 26, 2015}} Later that day, the governor declared a state of emergency. The travel ban was lifted for Fairfield and Litchfield Counties in western Connecticut at 8 a.m. on the 27th, and for the remainder of the state at 2 p.m. that afternoon.{{cite news|author=Jim Levulis|title=MA And CT Declare State Of Emergency, Issues Travel Bans As Winter Blast Nears|url=http://wamc.org/post/ma-and-ct-declare-state-emergency-issues-travel-bans-winter-blast-nears|work=WAMC Northeast Public Radio|date=January 26, 2015|accessdate=January 26, 2015}} ===Rhode Island=== Rhode Island Governor [[Gina Raimondo]] urged people to ensure that they had enough food, water, and fuel to last several days for what could be a "very severe and dangerous weather event". She asked residents to keep fire hydrants uncovered and asked that generators used for electricity were located outside of homes and in well-ventilated locations.{{cite news|title=RI governor: Prepare for possible dangerous weather event|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2015/jan/25/ri-governor-prepare-for-possible-dangerous-weather/|agency=Associated Press|date=January 25, 2015|accessdate=January 25, 2015}} On January 26, the governor declared a state of emergency and announced that a statewide travel ban would go into effect at midnight. National Grid gathered approximately 1,000 crews to help restore power after the storm passed.{{cite news|author=Dee DeQuattro|title=Raimondo announces State of Emergency for RI|url=http://www.abc6.com/story/27941695/state-of-emergency-announced-in-ri|work=ABC 6 News|date=January 26, 2015|accessdate=January 26, 2015}} ===Massachusetts=== [[File:harvard square store closed january 2015.jpg|thumb|right|220px|[[Harvard Square]] store closed in preparation for blizzard]] Massachusetts Governor [[Charlie Baker (politician)|Charlie Baker]] declared a state of emergency and asked residents to remain safe and off roadways. A statewide travel ban was issued effective at midnight on January 27, and the [[Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority]] announced that it would be closed that day. In [[Boston]], up to 35,000 tons of salt were prepared and snow farms were readied to store the removed snow following the passage of the storm. Electric companies brought in extra crews.{{cite news|title=State of emergency declared; travel ban imposed in Massachusetts|url=http://www.wcvb.com/weather/historic-blizzard-could-break-snowfall-records-in-mass/30918750|work=WCVB 5 News|date=January 26, 2015|accessdate=January 26, 2015}} The [[Fall River, Massachusetts]] Department of Public Works gathered more than 800 tons of salt and began to treat major roadways in advance of the storm.{{cite news|author=Colin Spence|title=SE Massachusetts makes preparations for blizzard|url=http://wpri.com/2015/01/26/se-massachusetts-preparing-for-blizzard/|work=WPRI 12 News|date=January 26, 2015|accessdate=January 26, 2015|location=Fall Rivers, Massachusetts}} ===Atlantic Canada=== Environment Canada issued special weather statements to all of the Maritime provinces on January 23, warning of the future developing storm. On January 26 Environment Canada issued Winter Storm Warnings for all of [[Nova Scotia]], [[Prince Edward Island]], and central to southern [[New Brunswick]]. These warnings were later upgraded to Blizzard Warnings. Between {{convert|6|and|20|in|cm}} of snow was forecast across the Maritimes. On January 27, Snow started early in the morning in southwestern Nova Scotia and continued northeastward. A large wind gust of {{convert|80|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} was measured in Baccaro Point, NS.{{cite web|title=Weather Data|url=http://climate.weather.gc.ca/climateData/dailydata_e.html?StationID=46007&timeframe=2&Year=2015&Month=1&cmdB1=Go#|publisher=Environment Canada|accessdate=27 January 2015}} Meanwhile, in Sluice Point there were gusts exceeding {{convert|70|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} in the afternoon.{{cite web|title=Weather data|url=http://www.wunderground.com/personal-weather-station/dashboard?ID=INOVASCO152#history/s20150127/e20150127/mdaily|publisher=wunderground|accessdate=27 January 2015}} In Moncton snow totaled near {{convert|11.8|in|cm}} the most out of all four provinces.{{cite web|title=Snowstorm hits the Maritimes|url=http://globalnews.ca/news/1795021/blizzard-of-2015-to-hit-the-maritimes-tuesday/|publisher=Global News|accessdate=27 January 2015}} The strong winds and blowing snow caused poor traveling conditions across Atlantic Canada. ==Impact== [[FlightAware]] reported that 1,200 flights were expected to be cancelled on January 26. Delta pre-emptively cancelled 600 flights; furthermore, a dozen flights from London Heathrow to New York, Philadelphia and Boston were cancelled on the same date.{{cite web|title=Weather NYC: Thousands of transatlantic travellers face serious disruption caused by New York winter storm 'Juno'|work=The Independent|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/new-york-winter-storm-juno-thousands-of-transatlantic-travellers-face-serious-disruption-10001882.html|date=January 26, 2015|accessdate=January 26, 2015}} At least two deaths related to the nor'easter occurred on [[Long Island]], [[New York (state)|New York]]. Sean Urda, a 17-year-old student from [[John Glenn High School (Huntington, New York)|John Glenn High School]], was killed when he struck a light pole while snow tubing with two other people in [[Huntington, New York|Huntington]].{{cite web|url=http://www.wcvb.com/weather/1st-death-of-storm-reported-teen-dies-after-sledding-accident/30938676|title=1st death of storm reported: Teen dies after sledding accident|publisher=WCVB}} An 83-year-old man with [[dementia]] was found dead in his backyard in [[Bay Shore, New York|Bay Shore]].{{cite web|url=http://www.newsday.com/long-island/suffolk/bay-shore-man-83-found-dead-on-long-island-police-say-1.9864034?qr=1|title=Bay Shore man, 83, found dead on Long Island, police say|work=Newsday|accessdate=January 28, 2015}} The [[National Basketball Association]] postponed two games scheduled to take place on January 26, both in [[New York City]]. The game between the [[Portland Trail Blazers]] and the [[Brooklyn Nets]] was rescheduled for April 6, while the game between the [[Sacramento Kings]] and the [[Manhattan]]-based [[New York Knicks]] was rescheduled for March 3.[http://hangtime.blogs.nba.com/2015/01/26/nba-postpones-tonights-games-in-new-york-area-due-to-weather-conditions/?ls=iref:nbahpts NBA POSTPONES TONIGHT’S GAMES IN NEW YORK AREA DUE TO WEATHER CONDITIONS] National Basketball Association.com (01/26/2015) [[WWE]] had events scheduled to take place in [[Hartford, Connecticut]] and in [[Boston, Massachusetts]], but had to cancel them, instead choosing to air [[Royal Rumble (2015)|Royal Rumble]] highlights. Significant flooding was reported in [[Scituate, Massachusetts|Scituate]], [[Massachusetts]], where National Guardsmen were sent to rescue people from the high waters{{cite web|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/metro/2015/01/27/scituate-officials-pluck-residents-from-flooded-homes-marshfield-investigates-collapsed-seawall/ALz0nWlHNdIxhkzntB1yVL/story.html|title=National Guard rescues Scituate residents|work=Boston Globe|accessdate=January 28, 2015}} and power was cut to some areas of the town to prevent fires from breaking out.{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/blizzard-15/massachusetts-town-scituate-cuts-power-prevent-flood-fires-n294181|title=Massachusetts Town of Scituate Cuts Power to Prevent Flood Fires|work=NBC News|accessdate=January 28, 2015}} Elsewhere in the state, eighty feet of [[seawall]] in [[Marshfield, Massachusetts|Marshfield]] was washed away by the storm, and a number of houses in the town were condemned.{{cite web|url=http://www.bostonherald.com/news_opinion/local_coverage/2015/01/scenes_from_juno_marshfield_seawall_crumbling_homes_condemned|title=Scenes from Juno: Marshfield seawall crumbling, homes condemned|author=Erin Smith|work=bostonherald.com|accessdate=January 28, 2015}} "Virtually all" utility customers lost power on the [[Nantucket|island of Nantucket]] and in [[Provincetown, Massachusetts|Provincetown]] on [[Cape Cod]] during the storm.{{cite news |first=Jay |last=Fitzgerald |title=Utilities emerge from storm with fewer outages than feared |url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/business/2015/01/27/thousands-lose-power-storym/awXQFhWumraJI78tAJnEeN/story.html |work=Boston Globe |date=January 27, 2015 |accessdate=January 28, 2015 }} A replica of the ''[[USS Providence (1775)|USS Providence]]'', maintained by the Providence Maritime Heritage Foundation and designated in 1992 as the [[List of U.S. state ships|flagship and tall ship ambassador]] of the state of [[Rhode Island]], was toppled and severely damaged by high winds during the storm while in [[drydock]] for the winter.{{cite web|url=http://www.stripes.com/news/us/uss-providence-damaged-after-falling-in-storm-s-strong-winds-1.326112|title=USS Providence damaged after falling in storm's strong winds|work=Stars and Stripes|accessdate=28 January 2015}} Snow from the storm fell as far south as parts of [[North Carolina]], southern [[Virginia]],{{cite web|url=http://www.richmond.com/news/article_9110d9a7-77a6-531f-9319-05e0269c4f23.html|title=Snow closes schools, causes wrecks goes away quickly|work=Richmond.com|accessdate=January 28, 2015}} [[Washington, D.C.]], and the [[Washington, D.C. metropolitan area]], where trace amounts were reported beginning on January 26.{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/capital-weather-gang/wp/2015/01/25/d-c-area-forecast-tricky-storm-brings-snow-tonight-into-monday-cold-start-to-the-work-week/|title=D.C. area forecast: Tricky storm brings snow tonight into Monday, cold start to the week|work=Washington Post|accessdate=January 28, 2015}} Schools in some Virginia counties were closed due to the weather.{{cite web|url=http://www.stardem.com/ap/state/article_b6aad498-4e8f-5bb8-a97e-a260e18953d1.html|title=Mid-Atlantic dealt 'glancing blow,' avoids worst of storm|work=stardem.com|accessdate=January 28, 2015}} ===Gallery=== {{Gallery |title=Images of snowfall accumulated during the blizzard |width=230 | height=250 |align=center |File:January 2015 nor'easter New York 08.jpg |Snowfall in [[Brooklyn|Brooklyn, New York]] on January 26 |File:Thayer Street during Juno.JPG |Snowfall in [[Providence, Rhode Island]] on January 27 |File:January 2015 nor'easter snowfall in Watertown, MA.jpg |Snowfall in [[Watertown, Massachusetts]] on January 27 |File:Massachusetts-New Hampshire border during the January 2015 nor'easter.jpg |Snowfall at the [[Massachusetts]]-[[New Hampshire]] border before noon on January 27 |File:Boston mailbox snow 2015.jpg |Snow covered mailboxes in Boston's [[Back Bay, Boston|Back Bay]] neighborhood after the January 2015 blizzard }} ===Records=== Up to The [[Blue Hill Observatory]] in [[Massachusetts]] observed {{convert|30.8|in|cm|abbr=on}}, or the second-largest storm total accumulation on record, while both [[Providence, Rhode Island]] and [[Portland, Maine]] recorded their fourth-largest storm total accumulations on record, at {{convert|19.1|in|cm|abbr=on}}. [[Image:Tml15-16 Nc.jpg|thumb|upright=1.6|Lake Nyos as it appeared eight days after the eruption]] On 21 August 1986, a [[limnic eruption]] at [[Lake Nyos]] in northwestern [[Cameroon]] killed 1,746 people and 3,500 livestock. The eruption triggered the sudden release of about 100,000–300,000 [[ton]]s (1.6m tons, according to some sources) of [[carbon dioxide]] ({{CO2}}).{{cite journal|url=http://www.nature.com/scientificamerican/journal/v293/n1/full/scientificamerican0705-49.html|title=Can We Bury Global Warming? (2005)|journal=Scientific American|date=July 2018|accessdate=December 14, 2012|volume=293|doi=10.1038/scientificamerican0705-49|pages=49–55}}{{cite journal|last=Mathew Fomine |first=Forka Leypey |journal=Australasian Journal of Disaster and Trauma Studies |volume=2011-1 |url=http://www.massey.ac.nz/~trauma/issues/2011-1/fomine.htm |title=The Strange Lake Nyos CO2 Gas Disaster |publisher=Massey University |year=2011 |issn=1174-4707 |accessdate=February 4, 2016}} The gas cloud initially rose at nearly {{convert|100|km/h}} and then, being heavier than air, descended onto nearby villages, displacing all the air and suffocating people and livestock within {{convert|25|km}} of the lake. {{cite web|url=http://www.geology.sdsu.edu/how_volcanoes_work/Nyos.html|title=Lake Nyos (1986)|publisher=[[San Diego State University]]|date=March 31, 2006|accessdate=December 19, 2008}}{{cite journal|last=Smolowe |first=Jill |title=Cameroon the Lake of Death |journal=[[TIME (magazine)|TIME]] |date=September 8, 1986 |volume=128 |issue=10 |pages=34–37 |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,962228-1,00.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090227160526/http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0%2C9171%2C962228-1%2C00.html |archivedate=February 27, 2009 |accessdate=December 9, 2013 |deadurl=yes |df= }} A degassing system has since been installed at the lake, with the aim of reducing the concentration of {{CO2}} in deep waters and therefore the risk of further eruptions. == Eruption and gas cloud == It is not known what triggered the catastrophic [[outgassing]].{{cite journal|last1=Cotel|first1=Aline J|title=A Trigger Mechanism for the Lake Nyos Disaster|journal=Journal of Volcanology and Geothermal Research|date=March 1999|volume=88|issue=4|pages=343–347|doi=10.1016/s0377-0273(99)00017-7|url=https://doi.org/10.1016/s0377-0273(99)00017-7}}{{cite journal|last1=Rouwet|first1=Dmitri|last2=Tanyileke|first2=Greg|last3=Costa|first3=Antonio|title=Cameroon's Lake Nyos Gas Burst: 30 Years Later|journal=Eos|date=July 12, 2016|volume=97|doi=10.1029/2016eo055627|url=https://doi.org/10.1029/2016eo055627}}{{oa}} Most geologists suspect a landslide, but some believe that a small volcanic eruption may have occurred on the bed of the lake.{{cite journal|last1=Rice|first1=A|title=Rollover in Volcanic Crater Lakes: A Possible Cause for Lake Nyos Type Disasters|journal=Journal of Volcanology and Geothermal Research|date=April 2000|volume=97|issue=1-4|pages=233–239|doi=10.1016/s0377-0273(99)00179-1|url=https://doi.org/10.1016/s0377-0273(99)00179-1}}{{cite book|last1=Aka|first1=FestusTongwa|title=Volcanic Lakes|date=2015|publisher=Springer Berlin Heidelberg|isbn=9783642368325|pages=467–488|url=https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007%2F978-3-642-36833-2_21|language=English|chapter-url= https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-642-36833-2_21|chapter=Depth of Melt Segregation Below the Nyos Maar-Diatreme Volcano (Cameroon, West Africa): Major-Trace Element Evidence and Their Bearing on the Origin of CO2 in Lake Nyos}} A third possibility is that cool rainwater falling on one side of the lake triggered the overturn. Others still believe there was a small earthquake, but as witnesses did not report feeling any tremors on the morning of the disaster, this hypothesis is unlikely. Whatever the cause, the event resulted in the supersaturated deep water rapidly mixing with the upper layers of the lake, where the reduced pressure allowed the stored CO2 to [[effervescence (chemistry)|effervesce]] out of solution.{{cite journal|last1=Kusakabe|first1=Minoru|last2=Ohsumi|first2=Takashi|last3=Aramaki|first3=Shigeo|title=The Lake Nyos Gas Disaster: Chemical and Isotopic Evidence in Waters and Dissolved Gases from Three Cameroonian Crater Lakes, Nyos, Monoun and Wum|journal=Journal of Volcanology and Geothermal Research|date=November 1989|volume=39|issue=2-3|pages=167–185|doi=10.1016/0377-0273(89)90056-5|url=https://doi.org/10.1016/0377-0273(89)90056-5}} It is believed that about {{convert|1.2|km3}} of gas was released.{{cite web|title=The Strangest Disaster of the 20th Century|url=http://www.neatorama.com/2007/5/21/the-strangest-disaster-of-the-20th-century/|publisher=Neatorama|accessdate=June 20, 2010|date=May 21, 2007}} The normally blue waters of the lake turned a deep red after the outgassing, due to [[iron]]-rich water from the deep rising to the surface and being [[oxidise]]d by the air. The level of the lake dropped by about a meter and trees near the lake were knocked down. Scientists concluded from evidence that a {{convert|100|m|abbr=on}} column of water and foam formed at the surface of the lake, spawning a wave of at least {{convert|25|m}} that swept the shore on one side.{{cite web|url=http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?date=20000201&slug=4002291|title=Scientists hope to quiet Cameroon's killer lakes|author=David Brown|publisher=''The Washington Post''|date=February 1, 2000|accessdate=December 19, 2008}} Carbon dioxide, being about 1.5 times as dense as air, caused the cloud to "hug" the ground and move down the valleys, where there were various villages. The mass was about {{convert|50|meters|ft}} thick, and travelled downward at {{convert|20|-|50|km/h}}. For roughly {{convert|23|km}}, the gas cloud was concentrated enough to suffocate many people in their sleep in the villages of Nyos, Kam, Cha, and Subum. About 4,000 inhabitants fled the area, and many of these developed respiratory problems, [[lesion]]s, and [[paralysis]] as a result of the gas cloud.Lake Nyos disaster, Cameroon, 1986: the medical effects of large scale emission of carbon dioxide?, BMJ, Volume 298, May 27, 1989, [http://www.pubmedcentral.nih.gov/articlerender.fcgi?artid=1836556] == Effects on survivors == [[Image:Cow killed by Lake Nyos gasses.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Cattle]] suffocated by carbon dioxide from Lake Nyos]] One survivor, Joseph Nkwain from Subum, described himself when he awoke after the gases had struck:
"I could not speak. I became unconscious. I could not open my mouth because then I smelled something terrible ... I heard my daughter snoring in a terrible way, very abnormal ... When crossing to my daughter's bed ... I collapsed and fell. I was there till nine o'clock in the (Friday) morning ... until a friend of mine came and knocked at my door ... I was surprised to see that my trousers were red, had some stains like honey. I saw some ... starchy mess on my body. My arms had some wounds ... I didn't really know how I got these wounds ... I opened the door ... I wanted to speak, my breath would not come out ... My daughter was already dead ... I went into my daughter's bed, thinking that she was still sleeping. I slept till it was 4:30 p.m. in the afternoon ... on Friday. (Then) I managed to go over to my neighbors' houses. They were all dead ... I decided to leave ... (because) most of my family was in [[Wum]] ... I got my motorcycle ... A friend whose father had died left with me (for) Wum ... As I rode ... through Nyos I didn't see any sign of any living thing ... (When I got to Wum), I was unable to walk, even to talk ... my body was completely weak."A. Scarth. [[USGS]], 1999.
Following the eruption, many survivors were treated at the main hospital in [[Yaoundé]], the country's capital. It was believed that many of the victims had been poisoned by a mixture of gases that included [[hydrogen]] and [[sulfur]]. Poisoning by these gases would lead to burning pains in the eyes and nose, coughing and signs of asphyxiation similar to being strangled.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/august/21/newsid_3380000/3380803.stm|title=21 August: 1986: Hundreds gassed in Cameroon lake disaster|publisher=BBC|author=BBC contributors|accessdate=December 19, 2008 | date=August 21, 1986}} == Aftermath == The scale of the disaster led to much study on how a recurrence could be prevented.{{Cite journal | last1 = Kling | first1 = G. W. | last2 = Evans | first2 = W. C. | last3 = Tanyileke | first3 = G. | last4 = Kusakabe | first4 = M. | last5 = Ohba | first5 = T. | last6 = Yoshida | first6 = Y. | last7 = Hell | first7 = J. V. | title = Degassing Lakes Nyos and Monoun: Defusing certain disaster | doi = 10.1073/pnas.0502274102 | journal = Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences | volume = 102 | issue = 40 | page = 14185 | year = 2005 | pmid = 16186504| pmc = 1242283}} Several researchers proposed the installation of degassing columns from rafts in the middle of the lake.{{cite journal|last1=Halbwachs|first1=Michel|last2=Sabroux|first2=Jean-Christophe|title=Removing CO2 from Lake Nyos in Cameroon|journal=Science|date=20 April 2001|volume=292|issue=5516|pages=438–438|doi=10.1126/science.292.5516.438a|url=https://doi.org/10.1126/science.292.5516.438a|language=en|issn=0036-8075}}{{cite journal|last1=Schmid|first1=Martin|last2=Halbwachs|first2=Michel|last3=Wüest|first3=Alfred|title=Simulation of CO2 Concentrations, Temperature, and Stratification in Lake Nyos for Different Degassing Scenarios|journal=Geochemistry, Geophysics, Geosystems|date=1 June 2006|volume=7|issue=6|doi=10.1029/2005GC001164|url=https://doi.org/10.1029/2005gc001164|language=en|issn=1525-2027}} The principle is to slowly vent the {{CO2}} by lifting heavily saturated water from the bottom of the lake through a pipe, initially by using a pump, but only until the release of gas inside the pipe naturally lifts the column of effervescing water, making the process self-sustaining.Degassing Lake Nyos project http://pagesperso-orange.fr/mhalb/nyos/nyos.htm Starting from 1995, feasibility studies were successfully conducted, and the first permanent degassing tube was installed at Lake Nyos in 2001. Two additional pipes were installed in 2011.{{cite web|url=http://pagesperso-orange.fr/mhalb/nyos/2000/index2000.htm|title=Degassing the "Killer Lakes" Expedition 2001|website=pagesperso-orange.fr}}{{dead link|date=April 2018}}{{cite web|url=http://www.universcience.fr/fr/science-actualites/film-as/wl/1248122455252/le-degazage-du-lac-nyos/ |title=Science Actualités – Ressources – Cité des sciences et de l'industrie – Expositions, conférences, cinémas, activités culturelles et sorties touristiques pour les enfants, les parents, les familles – Paris |publisher=Universcience.fr |date= |accessdate=October 17, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120103144659/http://www.universcience.fr/fr/science-actualites/film-as/wl/1248122455252/le-degazage-du-lac-nyos |archivedate=January 3, 2012 |df= }} Following the Lake Nyos disaster, scientists investigated other African lakes to see if a similar phenomenon could happen elsewhere. [[Lake Kivu]] in the [[Democratic Republic of Congo]], 2,000 times larger than Lake Nyos, was also found to be supersaturated, and geologists found evidence that outgassing events around the lake happened about every thousand years. ==In popular culture== A Greek novel by Basileios Drolias focusing on the lake Nyos disaster and the degassing of the lake was published in 2016. {{cite web |last = Drolias |first= Basileios | title = Nyos |publisher = Kedros | date = 2016 }} == References == {{Reflist|30em}} == External links == *[https://www.google.com/maps/place/Subum,+Cameroon/@6.4832826,10.259916,76622m/data=!3m2!1e3!4b1!4m5!3m4!1s0x1058ba88cbf8cb81:0xca8e2c82cd7e8b0b!8m2!3d6.483333!4d10.4?hl=en Google Earth view of the area around Lake Nyos] {{coord missing|Cameroon}} [[Category:1986 natural disasters]] [[Category:1986 in Cameroon]] [[Category:History of Cameroon]] [[Category:Natural disasters in Cameroon]] [[Category:20th-century volcanic events]] [[Category:Gas explosions]] [[Category:August 1986 events]]

{{short description|Discussion of variation in support for the theory of evolution by geopolitical distribution}} {{For|the scientific evidence supporting evolution|Evidence of common descent}} {{Evolutionary biology}}
The '''level of support for evolution''' among scientists, the public and other groups is a topic that frequently arises in the [[creation-evolution controversy]] and touches on educational, religious, philosophical, scientific and political issues. The subject is especially contentious in countries where significant levels of non-acceptance of evolution by general society exist although [[evolution]] is taught at school and university.
Nearly all (around 97%) of the scientific community accepts evolution as the dominant scientific theory of biological diversity.<ref name=pew/><ref>{{cite journal|url=http://nihrecord.od.nih.gov/newsletters/2006/07_28_2006/story03.htm |last=Delgado |first=Cynthia |title=Finding evolution in medicine |journal=NIH Record |volume=58 |issue=15 |accessdate=2007-10-22 |date=2006-07-28 |format=hmtl |ref=harv |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081122022815/http://nihrecord.od.nih.gov/newsletters/2006/07_28_2006/story03.htm |archivedate=2008-11-22 |df= }}</ref> Scientific associations have strongly rebutted and refuted the challenges to evolution proposed by [[intelligent design]] proponents.<ref name="dover_pg83">[[Wikisource:Kitzmiller v. Dover Area School District/4:Whether ID Is Science#Page 83 of 139|Ruling, Kitzmiller v. Dover page 83]]: "an overwhelming number of scientists, as reflected by every scientific association that has spoken on the matter, have rejected the ID proponents’ challenge to evolution."</ref>
There are religious sects and denominations in several countries for whom the theory of evolution is in conflict with creationism that is central to their beliefs, and who therefore reject it: in the [[United States]],<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.slate.com/id/1006378/ | title = George W. Bush, The Last Relativist | first = Timothy | last = Noah |date=2000-10-31 | accessdate = 2007-10-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://susanohanian.org/show_atrocities.html?id=2579 |title=Revealed: Tony Blair's link to schools that take the Creation literally |first=Nicholas |last=Pyke |publisher=[[The Independent]] |date=2004-06-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928001636/http://susanohanian.org/show_atrocities.html?id=2579 |archivedate=2007-09-28 |df= }} ; full article at {{cite web|last=Ohanian |first=Susan
